pageProps.body:
Node Features

Basics

Node Degree

du=∑v∈VAu,vd_u = \sum_{v\in V} A_{u,v}du​=∑v∈V​Au,v​

D=Diag(d)D =Diag(d)D=Diag(d)

Eigenvector Centrality

It's natural to define centrality as the solution of the recursive linear system:

eu=1λsumv∈VA[u,v]ev,∀u∈Ve_u = \frac{1}{\lambda}sum_{v\in V} A[u,v] e_v,\forall u\in Veu​=λ1​sumv∈V​A[u,v]ev​,∀u∈V

The eigenvector centrality vector would be λ=Ae\lambda = A eλ=Ae, where λ\lambdaλ is the largest eigenvalue of the adjacency matrix.

Random Walk probability View

The eigenvector centrality is the average time we spend in a given node as we do a random walk.

Can solve with the following power iteration: e(t+1)=Aete_(t+1) = A e_te(​t+1)=Aet​

if we start from e0=(1,1,...1)Te_0 = (1,1,...1)^Te0​=(1,1,...1)T, then ete_{t}et​ will contain the number of length-t paths that end in each node.

Betweenness Centrality

Closeness Centrality

Clustering Coefficient

This is the proportion of closed triangles in the neighborhood of a node.

Local Clustering Coefficient: cu=∑i∈N(u),j∈N(u)A[u,v]Cdu2c_u = \frac{\sum_{i\in N(u),j\in N(u)}A[u,v]}{C_{d_u}^2}cu​=Cdu​2​∑i∈N(u),j∈N(u)​A[u,v]​

    An interesting and important property of real-world networks troughout the social and
     biological sciences are that the local clustering coefficients tend to be much higher 
     than if they were to be sampled randomly.

Ego Graph

An ego graph around a node is the induced subgraph that contains only the node and its neighbors.

Then we can count triangles and other motiffs there and characterize the graph like this.

Graph Level Features

Bag of Nodes

Aggregate node-level statistics.

Weisfeiler-Lehman Kernel

Get a hash function hhh that takes a set of labels and returns a label

  1. Assign initial label to each node lu(0)l_u^{(0)}lu(0)​
  2. Iterate k times: get neighboring labels and hash them w/ hhh. This is the new label lu(i)l_u^{(i)}lu(i)​.
  3. look at the set lu(k){l_u^{(k)}}lu(k)​ . This summarizes, for each node, info about it's kkk-hop neighborhood.

Compute histograms or other summary statistics over these labels and use that as a feature representation of the graph.

Graphlets And Path-Based methods

Graphlets

Get graph patterns and count them. Combinatorially difficult, but there are approximations

Path-Based methods

Run limited-depth random walks from each node, gather stats about how much you've visited all nodes. Gather the histograpm of the counter of these nodes...

Can also count occurences of different degree sequences.

Node-Node Overlap Measures

Local Overlap Measures

These measures consider only the immediate neighbors of uuu and vvv.

S[u,v]=∣N(u)∩N(v)∣S[u,v] = |N(u)\cap N(v)|S[u,v]=∣N(u)∩N(v)∣

This provides a way to measure how similar 2 nodes are. We usually combine them with the assumption that the probability of having an edge is proportional to the similarity coefficient S[u,v] P((u,v)∈E)S[u,v]~ P((u,v)\in E)S[u,v] P((u,v)∈E)

SSorenson[u,v]=2∣N(u)∩N(v)∣∣du+dv∣S_{Sorenson}[u,v] = \frac{2|N(u)\cap N(v)|}{ |d_u+d_v|}SSorenson​[u,v]=∣du​+dv​∣2∣N(u)∩N(v)∣​

SSalton[u,v]=2∣N(u)∩N(v)∣du∗dvS_{Salton}[u,v] = \frac{2|N(u)\cap N(v)|}{ \sqrt{d_u*d_v}}SSalton​[u,v]=du​∗dv​​2∣N(u)∩N(v)∣​

SJaccard[u,v]=∣N(u)∩N(v)∣∣N(u)∪N(v)∣S_{Jaccard}[u,v] = \frac{|N(u)\cap N(v)|}{|N(u)\cup N(v)|}SJaccard​[u,v]=∣N(u)∪N(v)∣∣N(u)∩N(v)∣​

Importance-aware measures

It's a bit like a TF-IDF or other sort of normalizations.

Resource Allocation Index:

SRA[u,v]=∑u∈N(u)∩N(v)1duS_{RA}[u,v] = \sum_{u\in N(u)\cap N(v)} \frac{1}{d_u}SRA​[u,v]=∑u∈N(u)∩N(v)​du​1​

So the more 'special' a node in the overlapping neighborhoods of uuu and vvv is, the higher it's weight in SRA[u,v]S_{RA}[u,v]SRA​[u,v]

Adamic-Adar Index is quite similar:

SRA[u,v]=∑u∈N(u)∩N(v)1log(du)S_{RA}[u,v] = \sum_{u\in N(u)\cap N(v)} \frac{1}{log(d_u)}SRA​[u,v]=∑u∈N(u)∩N(v)​log(du​)1​

Global Overlap Measures

These are also between two vertices, but they consider the entire graph. E.g. in the 'following fish graph' A1A1A1 and A2A2A2 will be pretty similar, though they have 000 neighbors in common.

graph LR; A1-->B1-->C A2-->B2-->C C-->D1-->E C-->D2-->E

Katz Index

The most basic overlap statistics. It simply shows the number of paths of all lenghts between two vertices uuu and vvv, discounted:

Skatz[u,v]=∑i=1∞βiAi,jiS_{katz}[u,v] = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \beta^i A^i_{i,j}Skatz​[u,v]=∑i=1∞​βiAi,ji​

After some matrix algebra, we notice this index can be written as a matrix as follows:

Skatz=(I−βA)−1−IS_katz = (I-\beta A)^{-1}-ISk​atz=(I−βA)−1−I

Leicht, Holme, Newmann (LHN) Similarity Index

This is: Number of Paths of len I/(expected number of paths of len I) were the graph to be randomly generated with the same set of degrees.

To compute the expectation we can do it by sampling the graph.

Alternatively, there is the following analytical expressions:

E[A[u,v]]=dudv2∣E∣E[A[u,v]] = \frac{d_u d_v}{2|E|}E[A[u,v]]=2∣E∣du​dv​​

E[A2[u,v]]=dudv(2∣E∣)2∗∑u∈V(du−1)duE[A^2[u,v]] = \frac{d_u d_v}{(2|E|)^2}*\sum_{u\in V}(d_u-1)d_uE[A2[u,v]]=(2∣E∣)2du​dv​​∗∑u∈V​(du​−1)du​ ... But this doesn't scale for i>3.

There is some more math to approximate using the i−1i-1i−1-st smallest eigenvalue

...

S{LNH}[u,v] = I[u,v]+ \frac{2m}{d_u d_v}\sum{i=1}^{\infty} \beta^i \lambda_1^(1-i)) A^i[u,v]

See more at (2.22) in the book.

where I is an identity matrix

Random Walk Metrics

Personalized Pagerank

'What's the distribution of nodes visited by a random walker, starting from this node, who teleports back to the starting node with some probability?'

Let us define the stochastic matrix: P=AD−1P = AD^{-1}P=AD−1

Then the personalized PageRank with teleport-back probability 1−c1-c1−c:

qu=cPqu+(1−c)I[:,u]q_u = cPq_u + (1-c)I[:,u]qu​=cPqu​+(1−c)I[:,u] where I is the identity matrix.

Then qu=(1−c)(I−cP)−1euq_u = (1-c)(I-cP)^{-1}e_uqu​=(1−c)(I−cP)−1eu​

where eue_ueu​ is the unit vector with a 1 at index uuu and 0 otherwise.

Graph Laplacians and Spectral Methods

From Graph Laplacians
Go to text →

Let G=(V,E)G= (V,E)G=(V,E) be a graph and w:E−>R+0w:E->R^{+0}w:E−>R+0 be a weight function. Then let the degree matrix D be the diagonal matrix with Di,i=∑j∈Ew(i,j)D_{i,i}=\sum_{j\in E} w(i,j)Di,i​=∑j∈E​w(i,j). Let the corresponding adjacency matrix be Ai,j=wi,jA_{i,j} = w_{i,j}Ai,j​=wi,j​ Then the unnormalized Graph Laplacian is given by:

L=D−AL = D-AL=D−A

In the unweighted case, all edges have a weight of 1, and non-edges have a weight of 0.

We can show that LLL is positive semidefinite,that is, for any vector vvv in RnR^{n}Rn, vTLvv^TLvvTLv is non-negative.

Normalized Versions

Symmetric:

Lsym=D−1/2LD−1/2L_{sym} = D^{-1/2}LD^{-1/2}Lsym​=D−1/2LD−1/2

Random Walk Laplacian:

LRW=D−1LL_{RW} = D^{-1}LLRW​=D−1L

Laplacians and connected components: see

Go to text →

Approximation Via Laplacian Eigenvectors
